Description: RED SWAMP CRAYFISH (PROCAMBARUS CLARKII) ARE A WORLDWIDE INVADER THAT CAN NEGATIVELY IMPACT NATIVE SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS. THE FIRST DOCUMENTED POPULATION OF INVASIVE RED SWAMP CRAYFISH IN MICHIGAN OCCURRED IN JULY 2017. TO ADDRESS THE THREAT, MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY, UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, AUBURN UNIVERSITY, AND ADDITIONAL PARTNERS BEGAN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A MULTI-OBJECTIVE ADAPTIVE RESPONSE STRATEGY. THE INTERDISCIPLINARY COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS HAVE INCLUDED PATHWAY-BASED RISK ASSESSMENTS, EARLY DETECTION OF NEW INFESTATIONS, GENETIC EVALUATIONS OF SOURCES AND RELATEDNESS, EXTENSIVE MANUAL REMOVALS VIA TRAPPING, DEVELOPMENT OF ENGINEERING-BASED CONTROL ALTERNATIVES, AND PESTICIDE TREATMENTS. MAJOR ACCOMPLISHMENTS THUS FAR INCLUDE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF INTRODUCTION PATHWAYS, DELINEATION OF SEVEN INFESTATION COMPLEXES, INCREASED TRAPPING EFFICIENCIES, REMOVAL OF 170,000 INVASIVE CRAYFISH, EVIDENCE OF POPULATION SUPPRESSION, INCREASES IN NATIVE CRAYFISH SPECIES ABUNDANCE, AND EVALUATION OF SEVERAL INNOVATIVE CONTROL METHODS. NEW INFORMATION GAINED DURING RESPONSE EFFORTS HAS HELPED ADDRESS KEY UNCERTAINTIES AND IS INCORPORATED INTO FUTURE STRATEGIES IN AN ITERATIVE PROCESS. WITH THE PROPOSED PROJECT WE WILL BE ABLE TO CONTINUE OUR ADAPTIVE RESPONSE STRATEGIES DURING THE 2024 FIELD SEASON, WHICH WILL EMPHASIZE PESTICIDE TREATMENTS AT HIGH PRIORITY LOCATIONS, EVALUATION OF BIOCONTROL AND HABITAT MANIPULATIONS CONTROL METHODS, TRAPPING AND REMOVAL OF RED SWAMP CRAYFISH, AND EVALUATING CRAYFISH POPULATION DYNAMICS THAT WILL HELP INFORM FUTURE RESPONSE STRATEGIES.

INVASIVE CARP ARE ONE OF THE GREATEST THREATS TO NATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE AND A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH TO DEAL WITH THIS THREAT IS ESSENTIAL. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO PREVENT NEW INTRODUCTIONS, CONTROL EXISTING POPULATIONS, AND SEVER PATHWAYS. IN ADDITION TO THE CLEAR BENEFITS TO OHIO FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS, THESE ACTIONS PROTECT THE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS FISH AND WILDLIFE PROVIDE TO THE CITIZENS OF THE GREAT LAKES REGION AND POTENTIALLY REDUCE THE COST OF DEALING WITH FUTURE INVASIVE CARP ISSUES.THIS GRANT WILL BE USED TO FUND THE 2024 FIELD SEASON WITH AN INCREASE TO FOUR STRIKE TEAMS ALONG WITH THE MODELING AND RESEARCH EFFORTS TO SUSTAIN THIS INCREASED EFFORT.ADDITIONALLY, THE GREAT LAKES AND MISSISSIPPI RIVER WATERSHED DIVIDE WAS ASSESSED UNDER THE USACE GREAT LAKES MISSISSIPPI RIVER INTERBASIN STUDY TO DETERMINE IF THERE WERE VIABLE PATHWAYS FOR THE TRANSFER OF AIS. THE USACE CHARACTERIZED THE LIKELIHOOD THAT A VIABLE AQUATIC PATHWAY EXISTS AT LITTLE KILLBUCK CREEK, OHIO THAT WOULD ALLOW TRANSFER OF AIS BETWEEN THE GREAT LAKES AND MISSISSIPPI RIVERS BASINS. THIS WAS DETERMINED BY EVALUATING THE HYDROLOGIC AND HYDRAULIC CHARACTERISTICS OF THE SITE BASED ON READILY AVAILABLE INFORMATION AND CONDUCTING A SPECIES-SPECIFIC ASSESSMENT OF THE ABILITIES OF POTENTIAL AIS TO ARRIVE AT THE PATHWAY AND CROSS INTO THE ADJACENT BASIN. THE POTENTIAL AQUATIC PATHWAY SITE IS IN MEDINA COUNTY, OHIO, JUST NORTH OF THE WAYNE COUNTY BOUNDARY AND APPROXIMATELY 30 MILES (48 KILOMETERS) SOUTHWEST OF CLEVELAND. AT THE NORTH END OF THE LOCATION IS THE VILLAGE OF LODI AND AT THE SOUTHERN END IS THE VILLAGE OF BURBANK (IN WAYNE COUNTY).AS A RESULT OF THE MEDIUM RATING FOR THE PROBABILITY OF AN AQUATIC PATHWAY EXISTING AT LITTLE KILLBUCK CREEK, THE VIABILITY OF THIS PATHWAY FOR SPECIFIC AIS OF CONCERN WAS THEN EVALUATED BY LOOKING AT THE BIOLOGICAL REQUIREMENTS AND CAPABILITIES OF THE FOLLOWING AIS: SILVER CARP, BIGHEAD CARP, BLACK CARP, NORTHERN SNAKEHEAD, SKIPJACK HERRING, INLAND SILVERSIDE, THREESPINE STICKLEBACK, RUFFE, TUBENOSE GOBY, PARASITIC COPEPOD, EUROPEAN FINGERNAIL CLAM, AND EUROPEAN STREAM VALVATA, AS WELL AS VIRAL HEMORRHAGIC SEPTICEMIA (VHS).TO CLOSE THIS PATHWAY, THE PROJECT WILL BE PHASED OVER SEVERAL TEARS BASED ON RISK OF AIS TRANSFER. PHASE I OF THE PROJECT WILL BE FUNDED WITH THIS GRANT AND WILL BE LOCATED ON PROPERTY RECENTLY ACQUIRED BY MEDINA COUNTY PARK DISTRICT. THIS CONNECTION WILL BE SEVERED BY A ROCK BERM THAT WILL PREVENT AIS TRANSFER BUT ALLOW WATER TRANSFER TO REDUCE FLOODING RISK AND WILL CLOSE THE HIGHEST RISK AREA. FUTURE GRANT REQUESTS WITH COVER CONSTRUCTION OF PHASES 2 -7, PHASED OVER A FOUR-YEAR PERIOD STARTING IN 2025 AND WILL BE BASED ON AIS TRANSFER RISK.

GRASS CARP (CTENOPHARYNGODON IDELLA), A NON-NATIVE HERBIVOROUS FISH SPECIES, HAS THE POTENTIAL TO ALTER THE GREAT LAKES ECOSYSTEM BY CONSUMING LARGE AMOUNTS OF NATIVE AQUATIC VEGETATION. THE CONCERN OF GRASS CARP ESTABLISHING IN THE GREAT LAKES WAS ELEVATED FOLLOWING THE CONFIRMATION OF REPRODUCTIVELY VIABLE GRASS CARP IN LAKE ERIE IN 2012 AND FINDING OF EGGS IN 2015. SINCE THAT TIME, EARLY LIFE HISTORY SURVEYS HAVE DOCUMENTED EVIDENCE OF GRASS CARP SPAWNING IN THE SANDUSKY, MAUMEE, AND HURON RIVERS, LAKE ERIE TRIBUTARIES IN OHIO. A STRUCTURED DECISION MAKING PROCESS WAS INITIATED TO STRATEGICALLY ADDRESS REGIONAL CONCERNS AND KNOWLEDGE GAPS FOR GRASS CARP IN LAKE ERIE, WHICH LED TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE LAKE ERIE COMMITTEE GRASS CARP RESPONSE PLAN. IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PLAN IS A COORDINATED EFFORT AMONG MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO, UNIVERSITY OF BUFFALO, MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY, AND OTHER REGIONAL PARTNERS. TO DATE, OVER 600 GRASS CARP HAVE BEEN REMOVED FROM LAKE ERIE AND RESEARCH HAS HELPED ADDRESS CRITICAL UNCERTAINTIES SURROUNDING GRASS CARP LIFE HISTORY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF REMOVAL STRATEGIES. AS PART OF THE RESPONSE PLAN, PARTNER COLLABORATIONS HAVE CONTINUED TO ANALYZE CAPTURED INDIVIDUALS TO DETERMINE REPRODUCTIVE STATUS, NATAL ORIGIN, GROWTH DYNAMICS, AND MOVEMENT PATTERNS. IN ADDITION, PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMERCIAL FISHERS HAVE INCREASED TARGETED SAMPLING EFFORTS USING LARGE SEINES AND TRAP NETS, WHICH HAVE BEEN AN EFFECTIVE CAPTURE GEAR FOR GRASS CARP IN LAKE ERIE. THERE IS A NEED TO CONTINUE THIS IMPLEMENTATION AND MAINTAIN AGENCY CAPACITY FOR DEDICATED GRASS CARP MONITORING AND REMOVAL EFFORTS. ADDITIONALLY, EVALUATION OF TRADITIONAL AND OTHER NOVEL GEARS AND METHODS IS NEEDED TO IMPROVE RESPONSE EFFORTS. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE NEXT ITERATION OF THE ADAPTIVE RESPONSE PLAN IMPLEMENTATION BY FUNDING A MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES GRASS CARP FIELD CREW.

AQUATIC PLANT COMMUNITIES ARE CRUCIAL TO HEALTHY LAKE ECOSYSTEMS AND INVASIVE SPECIES CAN DISRUPT ECOLOGICAL BALANCE OF THE SYSTEMS. HOWEVER, THE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THAT ARE IMPLEMENTED TO ADDRESS AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANTS CAN ALSO CAUSE UNDESIRED IMPACTS TO WATER QUALITY, NATIVE SPECIES, AND WHOLE ECOSYSTEMS THEMSELVES. MANAGING THESE INVASIVE SPECIES CAN BE A COMPLEX AND POTENTIALLY CONTROVERSIAL TASK DUE TO THE VARIABILITY OF SPECIES AND MANAGEMENT IMPACTS. INVASIVE SPECIES ARE ONLY PRESENT AT HIGH POPULATION DENSITIES IN A RELATIVELY SMALL NUMBER OF OCCURRENCES, AND WHEN CHEMICAL TREATMENT IS DONE, IT CAN HAVE VARIABLE IMPACTS AND MAY OFTEN HAVE MORE IMPACTS TO NONTARGET NATIVE SPECIES THAN THE INVASIVE SPECIES BEING CONTROLLED. CONTRIBUTING TO THE COMPLEXITY IS A LACK OF INFORMATION ON INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANT MANAGEMENT TARGETED TO THE WATERFRONT PROPERTY OWNERS AND LAKE STAKEHOLDERS LIVING WITH THE IMPACTS OF THESE INVASIVE SPECIES.TO ADDRESS THESE CONCERNS, WE PROPOSE WORKING WITH TOPIC EXPERTS TO CREATE AN ADVERTISED WEBSITE FOR AQUATIC PLANT MANAGEMENT INFORMATION FEATURING A DECISION GUIDE THAT CAN HELP USERS UNDERSTAND POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF MANAGEMENT OPTIONS ON THEIR LAKE. CURRENT AQUATIC PLANT MANAGEMENT  APM  SCIENCE WILL BE SYNTHESIZED TO PRODUCE OUTREACH MATERIALS. THE SUBSEQUENT PRODUCTS WILL BE TESTED WITH WATERFRONT PROPERTY OWNERS, LAKE ORGANIZATIONS, AND LAKE USERS FOR IMPACTS ON KNOWLEDGE, ATTITUDES, AND BELIEFS. OUTREACH METHODS WILL BE EVALUATED TO UNDERSTAND HOW DIFFERENT APPROACHES IMPACT USER BEHAVIORS ON THE WEBSITE. A TRAINING FOR NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS WILL BE DEVELOPED AND HOSTED TO HELP WITH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE OUTREACH PRODUCTS. THE DIRECT RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL IMPROVE APM DECISION MAKING AND WILL LEAD TO MORE APPROPRIATE APPLICATIONS OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. THE RESULTS WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO OUTREACH EFFORTS THROUGH TRAINING AND READY-TO-USE PRODUCTS WHILE ALSO PROVIDING GENERAL INFORMATION ON OUTREACH FOR APM. THE TARGET AUDIENCES FOR THE OUTREACH PRODUCTS ARE WATERFRONT PROPERTY OWNERS, LAKE ORGANIZATIONS AND LAKE ORGANIZATION LEADERS. WE HOPE THAT LAKE ORGANIZATIONS AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS WILL BE ACTIVE IN PROMOTING THE OUTREACH PRODUCTS.OBJECTIVES AND OUTCOMES FOR THE PROJECT INCLUDE 1  DESIGN AND HOST A WEBSITE DEDICATED TO AQUATIC PLANT MANAGEMENT INFORMATION GEARED TOWARD WATERFRONT PROPERTY OWNERS, LAKE ORGANIZATIONS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS INTERESTED IN LAKES  30  OF EFFORT       A. THE MANAGEMENT OF ESTABLISHED AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AIS  POPULATIONS HAS LONG RELIED ON CHEMICAL AND PHYSICAL METHODS, OFTEN WITH UNWANTED NON-TARGET IMPACTS AND LIMITED SUCCESS. ONE NEW STRATEGY THAT HAS SHOWN PROMISE IS GENETIC BIOCONTROL  THE INTENTIONAL RELEASE OF GENETICALLY ENGINEERED ORGANISMS   OR PRODUCTS THAT INTEND TO INTERFERE WITH AN ORGANISM S GENOME   INTO THE ENVIRONMENT TO MANAGE A SPECIFIC TARGET SPECIES. GENETIC BIOCONTROL IS A POTENTIAL GAME-CHANGER IN THE MANAGEMENT OF AIS, BUT ITS SUCCESS WILL DEPEND ON MANAGING ECOLOGICAL, POLITICAL, AND SOCIAL RISKS AND UNCERTAINTIES.RESEARCH TO DEVELOP GENETIC BIOCONTROL STRATEGIES FOR AIS IS BEING CONDUCTED ON SEVERAL SPECIES RELEVANT TO THE GREAT LAKES REGION, INCLUDING COMMON CARP, NON-NATIVE PHRAGMITES, AND SEA LAMPREY, AND SOME TECHNOLOGIES MAY BE READY FOR SMALL-SCALE FIELD TRIALS WITHIN YEARS. IT IS THEREFORE PRUDENT THAT RESEARCHERS AND TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPERS WORK CLOSELY AND COMMUNICATE WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO UNDERSTAND POTENTIAL BENEFITS AND RISKS, IDENTIFY QUESTIONS AND CONCERNS, AND SHARE INFORMATION TO ADVANCE SCIENCE IN DIRECTIONS THAT ARE SAFE, EFFECTIVE, AND SOCIALLY ROBUST.THIS PROJECT TAKES THE FIRST STEP IN EXPLORING THE COMPLEX, SOCIO-POLITICAL ENVIRONMENT THAT WILL DETERMINE THE EVENTUAL SUCCESS OR FAILURE OF GENETIC BIOCONTROL TECHNOLOGIES TO CONTRIBUTE TO RESPONSIBLE AIS MANAGEMENT IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION. ACTIVITIES WILL ENGAGE KEY STAKEHOLDERS NOT JUST TO INFORM THEM, BUT TO INVITE THEM TO PARTICIPATE IN GOVERNING THIS EMERGING AREA OF RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT. AN ADVISORY BOARD WILL GUIDE OUR SELECTION OF STAKEHOLDERS AND THE SPECIFIC FORMATS OF OUR ENGAGEMENT.THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THREE PRIMARY GOALS. FIRST, WE SEEK CONTEXTUAL AND NUANCED UNDERSTANDINGS OF DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS  PERSPECTIVES ON RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF GENETIC BIOCONTROL APPROACHES TO AIS MANAGEMENT IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION. THIS WILL INFORM PATHWAYS OF INNOVATION AND CREATE BASELINE KNOWLEDGE FOR BROADER COMMUNITY AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT IN THE FUTURE. SECOND, WE WILL ORGANIZE AND FACILITATE MEANINGFUL, TWO-WAY ENGAGEMENT BETWEEN GENETIC BIOCONTROL INNOVATORS AND DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS IN ORDER TO CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR INFORMATION EXCHANGE, MUTUAL LEARNING, AND THE BUILDING OF TRUST. THIRD, ACKNOWLEDGING THE PROBLEMATIC HISTORY OF EXTRACTIVE SCIENTIFIC PRACTICES WITH RESPECT TO INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES, WE AIM TO CREATE PARTNERSHIPS THAT BEGIN TO LAY THE GROUNDWORK FOR COLLABORATION, CONSTRUCTIVE DIALOGUE, AND INCLUSIVE GOVERNANCE AMONG TRIBAL AND WESTERN SCIENTISTS, SOCIAL SCIENTISTS, RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND STAKEHOLDERS.OUTPUTS WILL INCLUDE  1  A LANDSCAPE ANALYSIS FOR THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF GENETIC BIOCONTROL TECHNOLOGIES FOR AIS MANAGEMENT IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION THROUGH INTERVIEWS OF STATE, TRIBAL, PROVINCIAL, AND FEDERAL AGENCY RESOURCE MANAGERS  2  A DIVERSE STAKEHOLDER ANALYSIS TO BROADEN AND CONTEXTUALIZE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF PERSPECTIVES, CONCERNS, AND PRIORITIES REGARDING GENETIC BIOCONTROL IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION  3  TWO WORKSHOPS THAT FACILITATE MEANINGFUL DIALOGUE AMONG RESOURCE MANAGERS, KEY STAKEHOLDERS, AND SCIENTISTS TO INFORM INNOVATION PATHWAYS FOR GENETIC BIOCONTROL OF AIS  AND 4  PARTNERSHIPS AND FUNDED COLLABORATIONS WITH TRIBAL SCIENTISTS, SOCIAL SCIENTISTS, AGENCIES, AND KEY STAKEHOLDERS  E.G., RESEARCH INITIATIVES LED BY TRIBAL SCIENTISTS OR SOCIAL SCIENTISTS, ADDITIONAL RESEARCH QUESTIONS, OR WORKSHOPS WITH TRIBAL COMMUNITIES ON TOPICS RELATED TO THE PROJECT THEME .THE PROJECT TEAM WILL REPORT TO A REGIONAL GOVERNANCE GROUP  ADVISORY BOARD  COMPOSED OF REPRESENTATIVES OF TRIBAL, STATE, PROVINCIAL AND FEDERAL AGENCIES ALONG WITH INVITED INDEPENDENT TECHNICAL ADVISORS AND FACILITATORS.

MORE THAN 3.2 BILLION LIVE ANIMALS WERE LEGALLY IMPORTED INTO THE U.S. DURING 2000-2014, AND UNTOLD NUMBERS OF LIVE PLANTS WERE ALSO IMPORTED. NONNATIVE PLANTS AND ANIMALS ARE ALSO DOMESTICALLY RAISED AND SOLD LIVE WITHIN THE U.S. THESE ORGANISMS WERE SOLD FOR USE IN VARIOUS TRADES INCLUDING AQUARIA, WATER GARDENS, CLASSROOM AND SCIENTIFIC SUPPLY, AQUACULTURE, AND LIVE-FOOD MARKETS.MANY SPECIES IN TRADE POSE RISKS OF IMPACTS TO THE ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION, INFRASTRUCTURE, ECONOMY, AND SOCIAL CONSTRUCTS AND FUNCTIONS WITHIN THE UNITED STATES. HOWEVER, NO RATING SYSTEM HAS BEEN PREVIOUSLY AVAILABLE TO ADVISE BUYERS AND SELLERS IN U.S. SUPPLY CHAINS OF THE RISKS AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, SAFE ALTERNATIVES THAT POSE LOW RISK OF DAMAGING IMPACTS TO AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS.ECOSTARTM IS THE FIRST OF ITS KIND RATING SYSTEM TO ADVISE INDUSTRY AND PUBLIC CONSUMERS ABOUT ECOLOGICALLY SAFE OPTIONS TO IMPORT, PRODUCE, SELL, AND BUY. TO DATE,18 LABELS FOR NONNATIVE SPECIES HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED AND HAVE BEEN VETTED BY EXPERTS IN ORGANISMS-IN-TRADE  OIT  SUPPLY CHAINS. ECOSTARTM LABELS ARE THE ONLY AVAILABLE RATING SYSTEM TO GUIDE SUPPLY CHAINS ABOUT WHICH SPECIES ARE SUSTAINABLE  I.E., LOW RISK , AND WHICH ARE NOT  I.E., HIGH RISK  IN THE U.S.THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT FROM AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES INTRODUCTIONS, BY MAKING SCIENCE-BASED, PLAIN-LANGUAGE LABELING  ECOSTARTM LABELS  INFORMATION AVAILABLE TO OIT SUPPLY CHAINS AND PUBLIC CONSUMERS. INFORMED DECISIONS, WITHIN SUPPLY CHAINS AND BY CONSUMERS, USING THESE LABELS WILL SUPPORT INFORMED SUSTAINABLE TRADE OPERATIONS IN NONNATIVE SPECIES. THROUGH FURTHER PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION, WILDLIFE FOREVER WILL DEVELOP TRADE ASSOCIATIONS PARTNERSHIPS, CONDUCT PUBLIC OUTREACH, AND DEVELOP 50 NEW ECOSTARTM LABELS. FOLLOWING DEVELOPMENT, WE WILL FACILITATE A STRATEGIC COMMUNICATION AND PUBLIC OUTREACH PROGRAM TO EDUCATE OIT RETAILERS AND PUBLIC CONSUMERS. IMPLEMENTATION OF A NATIONAL, LANDSCAPE SCALE ECOSTARTM PROGRAM, WILL BUILD ON CURRENT ACTIVITIES IN THE GL BASIN BEING PILOTED IN MINNESOTA AND WISCONSIN AND BUILD UPON PRODUCTS, PARTNERSHIPS AND RESOURCES DEDICATED TO OIT.

THE FOLLOWING ARE SHARED GOALS OF THE GLRI ACTION PLAN III  FISCAL YEAR 2020-2024  FOCUS AREA 2  INVASIVE SPECIES, THE WI DNR AIS PLAN, AND THE PROPOSED WORK FOR THIS GRANT  -PREVENT THE INTRODUCTION OF NEW AIS INTO WISCONSIN THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH BY IMPLEMENTING NEW PATHWAY INTERVENTION AND LOCAL NETWORK PROGRAMS. -CONTAIN THE SPREAD OF AIS IN WISCONSIN BY CONTINUED EXPANSION OF EARLY DETECTION AND SURVEILLANCE MONITORING, AND AN IMPROVED LOCAL NETWORK AND WATERCRAFT INSPECTION EFFORTS. -CONTROL EXISTING POPULATIONS OF AIS TO MINIMIZE HARMFUL IMPACTS WITH STRATEGIC CONTROL OF PIONEER STANDS OF NON-NATIVE PHRAGMITES.

CHARACTERIZATION OF DEMOGRAPHIC FEATURES OF NATURAL POPULATIONS IS IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTAND RECRUITMENT DYNAMICS, MATING SYSTEMS, AND PROPENSITIES FOR LOSS OF GENETIC DIVERSITY. ACCURATE IDENTIFICATION OF SEX CAN BE DIFFICULT IN SEXUALLY MONOMORPHIC SPECIES. WE WILL USE A MELT CURVE ANALYSIS BASED ON QPCR ASSAYS FOR LAKE STURGEON (ACIPENSER FULVESCENS) SEX IDENTIFICATION AND VALIDATION USING THE ALLWSEX2 MARKER. AGENCY PARTNERS WILL PROVIDE FIN CLIP SAMPLES FROM 1500 LAKE STURGEON. MEMBERS OF THE SCRIBNER LAB WILL (1) EXTRACT AND QUANTIFY DNA CONCENTRATIONS,(2) PREFORM QUANTITATIVE PCR AND MELTING CURVE ANALYSES TO ASSIGN SEX TO SAMPLES, (3) PROVIDE QUALITY CONTROL ASSESSMENT OF RESULTS OF ACCURACY IN THE FORM ON RE-ANALYSES OF A SUBSET OF SAMPLES, (4) PROVIDE A FINAL REPORT INCLUDING A TABLE OF GENETICALLY ASSIGNED SEX FOR ALL SAMPLES PROVIDED.

THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE DATA ESSENTIAL FOR A COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF CONTAMINANT EFFECTS ON COLONIAL WATERBIRD POPULATIONS, REPRODUCTION (EGG VIABILITY, FERTILITY, EMBRYONIC DEVELOPMENT AND DEFORMITIES, CHICK PRODUCTIVITY), AND HEALTH (CHICK GROWTH, AND IMMUNE RESPONSE) AT THE SAGINAW RIVER BAY BAY AND RIVER RAISIN AREAS OF CONCERN (AOCS). THIS RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES WITH SCIENTIFIC DATA IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GUIDANCE FOR DELISTING MICHIGANS GREAT LAKES AREAS OF CONCERN (MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, 2018) AND THE INTERNATIONAL JOINT COMMISSION (IJC 2001) TO EVALUATE THE BENEFICIAL USE IMPAIRMENTS (BUIS) OF DEGRADATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, AND BIRD OR ANIMAL DEFORMITIES OR REPRODUCTIVE PROBLEMS. CLEAN AND POSITIVE REFERENCES IN THE BASIN WILL BE ASSESSED FOR COMPARISONS. REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS WILL BE INDICATED BY COUNTING NESTS AND EXAMINING EGGS FOR HEALTHY EMBRYOS WITHOUT DEFORMITIES. CHICK HEALTH WILL BE EVALUATED BY GROWTH, WEIGHT PARAMETERS AS WELL AS IMMUNE RESPONSE ASSAYS DEVELOPED BY DR. GRASMAN. DR. GRASMAN WILL COORDINATE AND OVERSEE CONTAMINANT PREPARATION OF EGGS NOT ONLY FROM STUDY AND REFERENCE SITES BUT OTHER MONITORING LOCATIONS THROUGHOUT MICHIGAN REQUESTED BY STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNERS. PLASMA SAMPLES MAY ALSO BE USED FOR CONTAMINANT CORRELATIONS. USFWS WILL CONSULT ON ALL ASPECTS OF THE STUDY, ASSIST IN SAMPLE SHIPMENT, LABORATORY CONTRACTING, SITE PERMISSIONS, REPORT AND PRESENTATION DEVELOPMENT, AND DISSEMINATION OF RESULTING DATA TO MANAGEMENT AGENCIES.

THERE IS EVIDENCE THAT LONG-CHAIN PERFLUORINATED CARBOXYLIC ACIDS (LC-PFCAS), PERFLUOROOCTANOIC ACID (PFOA), PERFLUOROOCTANE SULFONATE (PFOS), POLYBROMINATED DIPHENYL ETHERS (PBDES), POLYCHLORINATED BIPHENYLS (PCBS), AND MERCURY (HG  HEREAFTER COLLECTIVELY REFERRED TO AS CONTAMINANTS OF MUTUAL CONCERN OR CMCS) ARE WIDELY DETECTED IN FISH ACROSS LAKE SUPERIOR, WITH POTENTIAL TO NEGATIVELY AFFECT THE ECOSYSTEM, INCLUDING THE BIRDS FOR WHICH THESE FISH ARE AN IMPORTANT FOOD SOURCE (POINT ET AL. 2021, BAYGI ET AL. 2021, SU ET AL. 2017, VENIER ET AL. 2010). MINNESOTA, WISCONSIN, AND MICHIGAN HAVE STATE FISH CONSUMPTION ADVISORIES IN EFFECT FOR LAKE SUPERIOR DUE TO PCBS, HG, AND PFOS. FISH ACCUMULATE CMCS FROM LOWER TROPHIC LEVELS AND CONTRIBUTE CMCS TO THEIR PREDATORS AT HIGHER TROPHIC LEVELS, THUS, THEY CAN BE USED TO UNDERSTAND HOW CMCS IN SEDIMENT AND WATER ACCUMULATE THROUGHOUT THE FOOD WEB AND POSE RISKS TO WILDLIFE THAT RELY ON FISH FOR FOOD. HOWEVER, THERE ARE SUBSTANTIAL GAPS IN KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THESE CMCS. THE CONCENTRATIONS AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF PERFLUORINATED COMPOUNDS (PFCS, INCLUDING LC-PFCAS, PFOA, AND PFOS) AND PBDES IN LAKE SUPERIOR AND HOW THESE CMCS ACCUMULATE IN THE FOOD WEB IS NOT WELL KNOWN AND THE NEED TO MONITOR FISH AND THEIR PREDATORS FOR PFCS IS EXPANDING.OBJECTIVES SUMMARY: DESCRIBE THE CURRENT CONCENTRATIONS AND DISTRIBUTIONS OF CMCS IN FISH AND THEIR PREDATORS (BALD EAGLES) ALONGTHE US LAKE SUPERIOR SHORELINE AND DESCRIBE RISKS TO WILDLIFE CONSUMING THESE FISH. ENHANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW CONTAMINANTS ACCUMULATE THROUGHOUT THE FOOD WEB. WHERE INFORMATION IS AVAILABLE, CHARACTERIZE TEMPORAL TRENDS TO HELP UNDERSTAND THE TRAJECTORY OF RISK FROMCMCS TO FISH AND THEIR CONSUMERS. IDENTIFY CMCS HOTSPOTS THAT SUPPORT TARGETED FUTURE MONITORING AND ARCHIVE INVESTIGATIONS.WISCONSIN FISH: WI DNR AIMS TO SAMPLE APPROXIMATELY 40 FISH AT APPROXIMATELY 4 LOCATIONS. ALL SAMPLES WILL BEANALYZED FOR PFCS, PCBS, AND HG, AND A SUBSET OF SAMPLES FROM TWO SPECIES OF RELATIVELY HIGH AND LOW TROPHICLEVELS (E.G., LAKE TROUT AND LAKE HERRING) WILL BE ANALYZED FOR PBDES. THIS WORK WILL EXPAND ON ROUTINE SAMPLINGTHAT OCCURS ON A FOUR-YEAR ROTATION TARGETING SPECIES GENERALLY CONSIDERED TO BE SPORT FISH TO EVALUATE FISHCONSUMPTION ADVISORIES, WITH THE PREVIOUS SAMPLING IN 2019. SPECIES ANALYZED WILL BE FISH SAMPLES FOR CHUBS ANDLAKE HERRING (POSSIBLY WALLEYE AND LAKE TROUT). CONCENTRATIONS AND TEMPORAL TRENDS OF CMCS WILL BE EXAMINEDACROSS ALL SPECIES. PFC MEASUREMENTS FOR EACH SPECIES WILL BE EXAMINED IN THE CONTEXT OF PCBS AND HG FOR WHICH THERE IS A LONGER TERM DATASET. REQUESTED FUNDING WILL SUPPORT CHEMICAL ANALYSES.WI DNR BALD EAGLES: IN 2023, WE WILL COLLECT BALD EAGLE CHICK PLASMA AND FEATHERS TO REPRESENT CURRENTCONDITIONS, INCLUDING AT LOCATIONS NEEDED TO FILL PREVIOUS SPATIAL GAPS IN SAMPLING. IF SAMPLES ARE UNABLE TO BECOLLECTED FROM TARGET SITES (E.G., NEST FAILURE), WE WILL USE ARCHIVED SAMPLES FROM AS FAR BACK AS 2017 TOREPRESENT CURRENT CONDITIONS IF ARCHIVED SAMPLES EXIST FOR THAT AREA. INTEGRATED BIODIVERSITY AND ECOSYSTEM ASSESSMENT IN REFERENCE AND RESTORED COMMUNITIES CAN HELP MAXIMIZE ECOLOGICAL BENEFITS OF HABITAT RESTORATION. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS WILDLIFE USE AND DISTRIBUTION, RIPARIAN CONNECTIVITY AND CONDITION ALONG A SERIES OF RESTORATION SITES ASSOCIATED WITH DAM REMOVAL AND CONTAMINANT CLEANUP VARYING IN PROGRESS ALONG THE KALAMAZOO RIVER. THE EFFECTS OF DAMS AND RESTORATION EFFORTS ON ECOSYSTEM COMPONENTS, INCLUDING RIVER CHANNEL STRUCTURE, WATER QUALITY, BENTHIC MACROINVERTEBRATES, FISH, AND RIPARIAN VEGETATION AND AQUATIC FOOD WEBS WILL BE EXAMINED.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EXAMINE THE CURRENT CONCENTRATIONS AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF CMCS IN FISH IN THE MICHIGAN NEARSHORE WATERS OF LAKE SUPERIOR. THE ABILITY TO IDENTIFY TRENDS IN CONTAMINANT EXPOSURE IS A VALUABLE TOOL FOR ASSESSING THE HEALTH OF FISH COMMUNITIES AND PISCIVOROUS WILDLIFE AS WELL AS LONG-TERM ECOSYSTEM HEALTH. FISH PROVIDE AN IMPORTANT FOOD SOURCE FOR HIGHER TROPHIC LEVEL SPECIES AS WELL AS REFLECT BIOACCUMULATION OF CONTAMINANTS AT LOWER TROPHIC LEVELS, MAKING THEM IMPORTANT IN LINKING ENVIRONMENTAL CONCENTRATIONS OF CMCS TO TOP-LEVEL PREDATORS, SUCH AS FISH-EATING BIRDS.

THIS STUDY AIMS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND CONCENTRATIONS AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF CHEMICALS OF MUTUAL CONCERN (CMCS) INCLUDING MERCURY (HG) ALONG THE US LAKE SUPERIOR SHORELINE. CMCS ARE WIDELY DISTRIBUTED AND HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO BIOACCUMULATE IN PISCIVOROUS SPECIES, MANY OF WHICH ARE IMPORTANT FOOD SOURCES FOR HUMANS. CMCS ARE KNOWN TO CAUSE DISEASE OR ARE ASSOCIATED WITH DISEASE IN BOTH HUMANS AND WILDLIFE. INVESTIGATION OF CMCS UNDER CURRENT CONDITIONS PROVIDES A BASIS FOR FUTURE INVESTIGATIONS THAT AIM TO MINIMIZE ADVERSE IMPACTS IN HUMANS AND WILDLIFE. THIS WORK CONTRIBUTES TO THE AIMS OF A COOPERATIVE PROJECT THAT WILL 1. DESCRIBE THE CURRENT CONCENTRATIONS AND DISTRIBUTIONS OF CMCS IN FISH ALONG THE US LAKE SUPERIOR SHORELINE AND DESCRIBE RISKS TO WILDLIFE CONSUMING FISH, 2. ENHANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW CONTAMINANTS ACCUMULATE THROUGHOUT THE FOOD WEB. 3. CHARACTERIZE TEMPORAL TRENDS TO HELP UNDERSTAND THE TRAJECTORY OF RISK FROM CMCS TO FISH AND THEIR CONSUMERS AND 4. IDENTIFY CMCS HOTSPOTS THAT SUPPORT TARGETED FUTURE MONITORING AND ARCHIVE INVESTIGATIONS.

THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (MDNR) HAS OPERATED A STATE OF MICHIGAN STATEWIDE BALD EAGLE PRODUCTIVITY FLIGHT SURVEY FOR MANY YEARS. THE PURPOSE OF THE SURVEY IS TO MONITOR EXISTING BALD EAGLE BREEDING AREAS, IDENTIFY NEW BREEDING AREAS, AND DETERMINE MATING PAIR NEST OCCUPANCY, EGG LAYING, EGG INCUBATION, HATCHING SUCCESS AND FLEDGING SUCCESS. MDNR LICENSED PILOTS WORK WITH MDNR AND INDEPENDENTLY CONTRACTED OBSERVERS. THE OBSERVERS AND A VOLUNTEER COMPILE PRODUCTIVITY DATA THAT IS THEN MADE AVAILABLE TO STATE, FEDERAL, AND ACADEMIC PARTNERS.THE DATA IS IMPORTANT TO THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT, GREAT LAKES, AND ENERGY (EGLE) AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) IN DETERMINING PRODUCTIVITY IN CERTAIN DESIGNATED AREAS OF CONCERN (AOCS) AS WELL AS IN NON-AOC REFERENCE LOCATIONS.THE SERVICE ALSO USES BALD EAGLE NEST DATA TO HELP INFORM PROJECT PLANNING AND TO ASSIST THE PUBLIC IN FEDERAL COMPLIANCE. THE MDNR BALD EAGLE PRODUCTIVITY FLIGHT SURVEY IS NECESSARY TO ADDRESS STATE AND FEDERAL PRIORITIES.TASKS:1.THE MDNR WILL OPERATE THE 2023 BALD EAGLE PRODUCTIVITY FLIGHT SURVEY.2.THE MDNR WILL WORK WITH OBSERVERS TO PROVIDE THE BALD EAGLE PRODUCTIVITY FLIGHT SURVEY METHODOLOGY IN A WRITTEN FORM (E.G., STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE, REPORT, OR MEMORANDUM).3.THE MDNR WILL OVERSEE THE TIMELY TRANSFER OF BALD EAGLE PRODUCTIVITY DATA TO THE USFWS, EGLE AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND.DELIVERABLES:1.BALD EAGLE PRODUCTIVITY DATA.2.BALD EAGLE FLIGHT SURVEY METHOD.

ACOUSTIC SAMPLING WILL LIKELY BE AN IMPORTANT TOOL IN THE ASSESSMENT OF COREGONINE POPULATION RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE GREAT LAKES BECAUSE NO OTHER TOOL CAN EFFECTIVELY SAMPLE ACROSS SUCH A LARGE GEOGRAPHIC RANGE WHILE ALSO ASSESSING THE WATER COLUMN. SPECIES SUCH AS BLOATER AND SHORTJAW CISCO AND LAKE WHITEFISH ARE PARTIALLY TO MOSTLY DEMERSAL, WHICH PRESENTS A CHALLENGE FOR ACOUSTIC ENUMERATION DUE TO THE BOTTOM ASSOCIATED ACOUSTIC DEAD ZONE (ADZ). THUS, REPORTED ACOUSTIC ESTIMATES FOR THESE DEMERSAL SPECIES ARE CONSERVATIVE. MARINE RESEARCHERS HAVE DEVELOPED METHODS FOR CORRECTING THESE CONSERVATIVE ACOUSTIC ESTIMATES OF ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT DEMERSAL SPECIES INCLUDING COD, HADDOCK AND WALLEYE POLLOCK, HOWEVER, SIMILAR METHODS HAVE NOT BEEN ATTEMPTED ON THE GREAT LAKES. WE PROPOSE DEVELOP ADZ CORRECTION METHODS FOR LOCATIONS IN LAKE SUPERIOR NEAR GRAND ISLAND, MICHIGAN, WHICH HAS A MULTISPECIES COREGONINE ASSEMBLAGE (ROUND WHITEFISH, CISCO, BLOATER, LAKE WHITEFISH, AND REPUTED SHORTJAW CISCO AND BLACKFIN CISCO), AND A NORTHERN LAKE HURON LOCATION HAVING ROUND WHITEFISH, CISCO, BLOATER AND LAKE WHITEFISH. BY DESCRIBING HOW DIFFERENT COREGONINE SPECIES ARE DISTRIBUTED RELATIVE TO THE LAKEBED DURING ISO THERMAL AND THERMAL STRATIFICATION PERIODS, WE WILL ACQUIRE THE NECESSARY DATA TO APPLY CONDITION SPECIFIC ADZ CORRECTION METHODS. OUR OBJECTIVES WILL BE TO SAMPLE AREAS WHERE BENTHO PELAGIC AND DEMERSAL COREGONINE SPECIES CURRENTLY ARE FOUND TO  1) ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE OF THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION OF COREGONINES THAT HAVE OR ARE LIKELY TO BE REINTRODUCED IN THE LOWER GREAT LAKES, 2) DESCRIBE SEASON SPECIFIC DEPTH DISTRIBUTION COREGONINES, AND 3) DEVELOP DETAILED UNDERSTANDING OF CHARACTERISTICS THE ACOUSTIC SIGNATURES OF KNOWN COREGONINES USING TREE BASED MODELS THAT PROVIDE CORRECTIONS FOR FISH FOUND IN THE ADZ.

BROOK TROUT (SALVELINUS FONTINALIS) AND LAKE TROUT (S. NAMAYCUSH) ARE THE ONLY CHARR NATIVE TO THE GREAT LAKES, AND ARE CULTURALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES THAT SUPPORT ECONOMICALLY VALUABLE FISHERIES AND ARE FOUNDATIONAL TO THE ECOLOGICAL HEALTH OF THE REGION. HOWEVER, SINCE THE EARLY 1900S, GENETIC AND PHENOTYPIC DIVERSITY OF BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT IN LAKE SUPERIOR HAVE DECLINED, RESULTING IN DIMINISHED GENE POOLS IN BOTH SPECIES. HATCHERY STOCKING HAS PLAYED AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN REHABILITATION EFFORTS, BUT INFORMATION ON THE GENOMIC IMPACTS OF HATCHERY STOCKING ON WILD BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT IS INCOMPLETE. IN PARTICULAR, STOCKING OF SPLAKE, AN ANTHROPOGENIC HYBRID OF BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT, HAS OCCURRED IN LAKE SUPERIOR SINCE THE 1970S. IT IS NOT KNOWN WHETHER SPLAKE INTROGRESS WITH BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT IN THE WILD, BUT PREVIOUS STUDIES OF GENETIC RELATIONSHIPS AND REPRODUCTIVE BIOLOGY INDICATE THE POTENTIAL FOR INTERBREEDING. INTROGRESSION IS OFTEN OVERLOOKED AS A THREAT TO NATIVE FISH BUT CAN SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE THE GENETIC HEALTH OF SPECIES. IF INTROGRESSION OF SPLAKE ALLELES INTO WILD POPULATIONS OF BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT IS OCCURRING, UNDERSTANDING THE RESULTING GENOMIC AND PHENOTYPIC IMPACTS WILL BE CRITICAL TO SUPPORTING HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT. HERE, WE AIM TO EXAMINE POTENTIAL EFFECTS OF SPLAKE INTROGRESSION ON THE HEALTH AND RECOVERY OF BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT ACROSS THE U.S. PORTION OF THE LAKE SUPERIOR BASIN. WE WILL CONDUCT RESTRICTION SITE ASSOCIATED DNA SEQUENCING IN WILD CAUGHT BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT TO DETERMINE WHETHER SPLAKE INTROGRESSION IS OCCURRING AND, IF SO, IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS WHERE INTROGRESSION IS OCCURRING. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL EMPLOY LOW COVERAGE WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING OF KNOWN HATCHERY CROSSES TO ASSESS SURVIVORSHIP AND EXAMINE THE PHENOTYPIC EFFECTS OF SPLAKE INTROGRESSION IN BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT, AND TO PROVIDE A REFERENCE FOR DISTINGUISHING INTROGRESSION IN WILD INDIVIDUALS. FINALLY, WE WILL LEVERAGE THE GENOMIC DATASETS PRODUCED HERE TO ADDRESS ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS CENTRAL TO THE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT, INCLUDING ASSESSING THE HEALTH OF GENETICALLY DISTINCT POPULATIONS AND INFERRING INTROGRESSION FROM STOCKED CONSPECIFICS. RESULTS FROM OUR PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT BY PROVIDING CRITICAL INFORMATION ON THE IMPACTS OF SPLAKE STOCKING, A MORE COMPREHENSIVE UNDERSTANDING OF BOTH BROOK TROUT AND LAKE TROUT GENETIC HEALTH IN LAKE SUPERIOR, AND IDENTIFYING TARGET AREAS FOR MANAGEMENT INTERVENTION.

RED SWAMP CRAYFISH  PROCAMBARUS CLARKII  ARE A WORLDWIDE INVADER THAT CAN NEGATIVELY IMPACT NATIVE SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS  THE FIRST DOCUMENTED POPULATION OF INVASIVE RED SWAMP CRAYFISH IN MICHIGAN OCCURRED IN JULY 2017  TO ADDRESS THE THREAT, MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY, UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, AUBURN UNIVERSITY, AND ADDITIONAL PARTNERS BEGAN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A MULTI OBJECTIVE ADAPTIVE RESPONSE STRATEGY  THE INTERDISCIPLINARY COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS HAVE INCLUDED PATHWAY BASED RISK ASSESSMENTS, EARLY DETECTION OF NEW INFESTATIONS, GENETIC EVALUATIONS OF SOURCES AND RELATEDNESS, EXTENSIVE MANUAL REMOVALS VIA TRAPPING, DEVELOPMENT OF ENGINEERING BASED CONTROL ALTERNATIVES, AND PESTICIDE TREATMENTS  MAJOR ACCOMPLISHMENTS THUS FAR INCLUDE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF INTRODUCTION PATHWAYS, DELINEATION OF SEVEN INFESTATION COMPLEXES, INCREASED TRAPPING EFFICIENCIES, REMOVAL OF 150,000 INVASIVE CRAYFISH, EVIDENCE OF POPULATION SUPPRESSION, INCREASES IN NATIVE CRAYFISH SPECIES ABUNDANCE, AND EVALUATION OF SEVERAL INNOVATIVE CONTROL METHODS  NEW INFORMATION GAINED DURING RESPONSE EFFORTS HAS HELPED ADDRESS KEY UNCERTAINTIES AND IS INCORPORATED INTO FUTURE STRATEGIES IN AN ITERATIVE PROCESS  WITH THE PROPOSED PROJECT WE WILL BE ABLE TO CONTINUE OUR ADAPTIVE RESPONSE STRATEGIES DURING THE 2023 FIELD SEASON, WHICH WILL EMPHASIZE PESTICIDE TREATMENTS AT HIGH PRIORITY LOCATIONS, TRAPPING AND REMOVAL OF RED SWAMP CRAYFISH, AND EVALUATING CRAYFISH POPULATION DYNAMICS THAT WILL HELP INFORM FUTURE RESPONSE STRATEGIES

HYDRILLA  HYDRILLA VERTICILLATA  IS AN AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT THAT IS BOTH A FEDERALLY LISTED NOXIOUS WEED PROHIBITED FROM INTERSTATE TRANSPORT AND ITS SALE, POSSESSION, TRANSPORT, AND PROPAGATION ARE PROHIBITED IN NEW YORK STATE  6 NYCRR PART 575   HYDRILLA WAS FIRST DISCOVERED IN CAYUGA LAKE AT AURORA IN 2016  SINCE THE DISCOVERY U S  ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS  USACE , FINGER LAKES PARTNERSHIP FOR REGIONAL INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT  FL PRISM , AND THEIR CONTRACTOR HAVE BEEN CONDUCTING AQUATIC PLANT SURVEYS AND MONITORING, TUBER DENSITY SURVEYS, AND HERBICIDE TREATMENTS TO REDUCE HYDRILLA COVERAGE NEAR AURORA  UNFORTUNATELY, IN 2021 IT WAS DISCOVERED VIA SCUBA AND SNORKELING SURVEYS THAT THE INFESTED AREA HAD MORE THAN DOUBLED IN SIZE  NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION  NYSDEC , WORKING CLOSELY WITH OUR PARTNERS, WILL ADVANCE TREATMENT TO NEW AREAS OF SPREAD IN AN EFFORT TO CONTROL AND PREVENT THE SPREAD OF HYDRILLA TO NEW LOCATIONS WITHIN CAYUGA LAKE AND THE FINGER LAKES REGION  WE WILL ALSO SUPPORT NATIONAL RESEARCH BEING CONDUCTED BY DR  SUSAN WILDE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA  DR  WILDE WILL TEST HYDRILLA SAMPLES FOR CYANOBACTERIA THAT PRODUCES TOXINS WHICH ARE DEADLY TO MANY VERTEBRATES INCLUDING WATERFOWL AND BALD EAGLES  AETOKTHONOS HYDRILLICOLA

INVASIVE CARP MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL IN THE ILLINOIS WATERWAY, CAFWS 164

GRASS CARP  CTENOPHARYNGODON IDELLA , A NON NATIVE HERBIVOROUS FISH SPECIES, HAS THE POTENTIAL TO ALTER THE GREAT LAKES ECOSYSTEM BY CONSUMING LARGE AMOUNTS OF NATIVE AQUATIC VEGETATION  THE CONCERN OF GRASS CARP ESTABLISHING IN THE GREAT LAKES WAS ELEVATED FOLLOWING THE CONFIRMATION OF REPRODUCTIVELY VIABLE GRASS CARP IN LAKE ERIE IN 2012 AND FINDING OF EGGS IN 2015  SINCE THAT TIME, EARLY LIFE HISTORY SURVEYS HAVE DOCUMENTED EVIDENCE OF GRASS CARP SPAWNING IN THE SANDUSKY AND MAUMEE RIVERS, TWO LAKE ERIE TRIBUTARIES IN OHIO  A STRUCTURED DECISION MAKING PROCESS WAS INITIATED TO STRATEGICALLY ADDRESS REGIONAL CONCERNS AND KNOWLEDGE GAPS FOR GRASS CARP IN LAKE ERIE, WHICH LED TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE LAKE ERIE COMMITTEE GRASS CARP RESPONSE PLAN  IMPLEMENTTION OF THE PLAN IS A COORDINATED EFFORT AMONG MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, U S  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO, MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY, AND OTHER PARTNERS  TO DATE, OVER 600 GRASS CARP HAVE BEEN REMOVED FROM LAKE ERIE AND RESEARCH HAS HELPED ADDRESS CRITICAL UNCERTAINTIES SURROUNDING GRASS CARP LIFE HISTORY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF REMOVAL STRATEGIES  AS PART OF THE RESPONSE PLAN, PARTNER COLLABORATIONS HAVE CONTINUED TO ANALYZE CAPTURED INDIVIDUALS TO DETERMINE REPRODUCTIVE STATUS, NATAL ORIGIN, GROWTH DYNAMICS, AND MOVEMENT PATTERNS  IN ADDITION, PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMERCIAL FISHERS HAVE INCREASED TARGETED SAMPLING EFFORTS USING LARGE SEINES AND TRAP NETS, WHICH HAVE BEEN AN EFFECTIVE CAPTURE GEAR FOR GRASS CARP IN LAKE ERIE  THERE IS A NEED TO CONTINUE THIS IMPLEMENTATION AND MAINTAIN AGENCY CAPACITY FOR DEDICATED GRASS CARP MONITORING AND REMOVAL EFFORTS  ADDITIONALLY, EVALUATION OF TRADITIONAL AND OTHER NOVEL GEARS AND METHODS IS NEEDED TO IMPROVE RESPONSE EFFORTS  THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE NEXT ITERATION OF THE ADAPTIVE RESPONSE PLAN IMPLEMENTATION BY FUNDING A MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES GRASS CARP FIELD CREW

THE GREAT LAKES ARE THREATENED BY THE POTENTIAL INTRODUCTION, ESTABLISHMENT AND SPREAD OF NEW AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  THE GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE ACTION PLAN III, INVASIVE SPECIES FOCUS AREA IDENTIFIED ONE OF ITS COMMITMENTS AS  DEVELOP ENHANCE INVASIVE SPECIES SPECIFIC COLLABORATIVES TO SUPPORT RAPID RESPONSES AND COMMUNICATE THE LATEST CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES   THE PROJECT DIRECTLY SUPPORTS THIS FEDERAL COMMITMENT THROUGH THE EXPANSION AND ENHANCEMENT OF THE EUROPEAN FROG BIT  EFB  COLLABORATIVE EUROPEAN FROG BIT  HYDROCHARIS MORSUS RANE L   IS AN INVASIVE FREE FLOATING AQUATIC PLANT OF GROWING CONCERN TO WATER RESOURCE MANAGERS, WATERFRONT PROPERTY OWNERS, AND RECREATIONAL USERS DUE TO ITS CONTINUED SPREAD AND POTENTIAL NEGATIVE EFFECTS ON GREAT LAKES COASTAL WETLANDS AND INLAND WATERS AND WETLANDS  THE EFB COLLABORATIVE WAS ESTABLISHED IN FALL OF 2018 TO IMPROVE COORDINATION AND COLLABORATION AMONG STAKEHOLDERS AND BUILD CONSENSUS ON NEXT STEPS FOR EFB MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH IN MICHIGAN  RECENT EFB DETECTIONS IN ADDITIONAL GREAT LAKES JURISDICTIONS INCLUDING OHIO, PENNSYLVANIA, NEW YORK, AND ONTARIO HAVE CAUSED EFB TO BECOME A MANAGEMENT PRIORITY IN A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OF THE BASIN RESULTING IN STATE AND TRIBAL INTEREST TO EXPAND THE EFB COLLABORATIVE BEYOND MICHIGAN THE PROJECT ADDRESSES SPECIFIC NEEDS IDENTIFIED DURING THE EFB COLLABORATIVE MEETING IN DECEMBER 2021 TO ENHANCE THE EXISTING COLLABORATIVE AND INTEGRATED WORK GROUPS BY EXPANDING THE REACH, ENHANCING THE EFB ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK, AND ESTABLISHING A SYSTEM OF GOVERNANCE THAT INCLUDES THE GREAT LAKES COMMISSION SERVING AS THE NEUTRAL BACKBONE ORGANIZATION  THROUGH THIS PROPOSED EFFORT, A NEW WEBSITE WILL BE ESTABLISHED TO SERVE AS A CENTRAL RESOURCE FOR EFB RESEARCH, MANAGEMENT, AND OUTREACH AS IT APPLIES TO THE GREAT LAKES BASIN  THE THREE PREVIOUSLY ESTABLISHED WORK GROUPS  INCLUDING DELIMITATION, MANAGEMENT ASSESSMENT, AND EDUCATION OUTREACH  WILL BE SUPPORTED AS THEY MAKE PROGRESS ON THEIR VARIOUS CHARGES  THE AMF WILL BE EVALUATED AND ADJUSTED TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE EXPANDED COLLABORATIVE NETWORK THE GOAL OF THIS COLLABORATIVE PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE INTERJURISDICTIONAL COORDINATION AND COLLABORATION AMONG STAKEHOLDERS AND BUILD CONSENSUS ON NEXT STEPS FOR EUROPEAN FROG BIT MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH  IT WILL ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES OBJECTIVE 1  ENHANCE AND EXPAND THE EFB COLLABORATIVE  FORMALIZED GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE THAT INCLUDES A STEERING  ADVISOR COMMITTEE AND WORK GROUPS WITH FORMAL PROMOTE INFORMATION SHARING  ESTABLISHED WEBINAR SERIES WITH AT LEAST FOUR WEBINARS  PRESENTATIONS DELIVERED AT ONE OR MORE RELEVANT CONFERENCES BY THE END OF THE FUNDING PERIOD  PUBLISHED BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES SPECIFIC TO EFBOBJECTIVE 3  IDENTIFY PRIORITY SITES FOR EFB MANAGEMENT  CONTAINMENT ZONES FOR HIGH RISK EFB INFESTATIONS ARE ESTABLISHED  INVADED HIGH VALUE SITES ARE IDENTIFIED AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES ARE ONE OF THE GREATEST THREATS TO NATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE AND A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH TO DEAL WITH THIS THREAT IS ESSENTIAL  THIS PROJECT FACILITATES A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH AND IS INTENDED TO PREVENT NEW INTRODUCTIONS, CONTROL, OR ERADICATE EXISTING AIS, AND SEVER AIS PATHWAYS IN THE LAKE ERIE WATERSHED  IN ADDITION TO THE CLEAR BENEFITS TO GREAT LAKES FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS, THESE ACTIONS PROTECT THE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS FISH AND WILDLIFE PROVIDE TO THE CITIZENS OF THE GREAT LAKES REGION AND POTENTIALLY REDUCE THE COST OF DEALING WITH FUTURE AIS ISSUES OUR CURRENT AIS ACTIVITIES IN THE LAKE ERIE WATERSHED INCLUDE  1  PROVIDE LEADERSHIP FOR AIS ACTIVITIES IN OHIO AND PARTICIPATE IN REGIONAL INITIATIVES, 2  SURVEILLANCE FOR HIGH PRIORITY AIS, 3  BAIT AND PET TRADE SURVEILLANCE AND OUTREACH, AND 4  INVASIVE PLANT SURVEILLANCE, OUTREACH, AND CONTROL

THIS SCOPE OF WORK IS BEING SUBMITTED BY THE PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIVERSITY ON BEHALF OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA. IT WAS DEVELOPED IN COLLABORATION WITH PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIVERSITY-SEA GRANT, THE WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA CONSERVANCY, PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES, AND THE PENNSYLVANIA FISH AND BOAT COMMISSION, WITH INPUT FROM OTHER STATE AGENCIES, ORGANIZATIONS, AND KEY STAKEHOLDERS, AND SUPPORTS THE GOALS AND MANAGEMENT PLANS OF THE PENNSYLVANIA INVASIVE SPECIES COUNCIL AND THE GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE ACTION PLAN III. THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE CRUCIAL SUPPORT FOR PENNSYLVANIA TO ADDRESS CURRENT AND INCREASING THREATS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) TO THE NATURAL RESOURCES OF LAKE ERIE AND THE GREAT LAKES. THESE ENTITIES PROPOSE TO USE THIS FUNDING TO TAKE A MULTIFACETED APPROACH TO CONTINUING THE WORK OF AIS PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION, MONITORING, RAPID RESPONSE, AND CONTROL WITH PROJECTS TO:PROJECT 1: TARGETED HYDRILLA VERTICILLATA RESPONSEPROJECT 2: INTERRUPTING THE BOATER/ANGLER PATHWAY - AN IDENTIFICATION RESOURCE FOR BAIT DEALERS TO PREVENT THE INTRODUCTION AND SPREAD OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PROJECT 3: CONDUCTING AN AIS MOCK RAPID RESPONSE EXERCISEPROJECT 4: LAKE ERIE WATERSHED COOPERATIVE WEED MANAGEMENT AREA COORDINATED CONTROL EFFORTSPROJECT 5: AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES THREATS TO THE LAKE ERIE WATERSHED - A SHORT FILMPROJECT 6: EARLY DETECTION SURVEYS OF PFBC LAKES FOR AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES THREATS TO THE LAKE ERIE BASINLAKE ERIE WILL BE THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARY OF THIS WORK ON PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION, MONITORING, AND CONTROL. THE WATERS OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA WILL BE A SECONDARY BENEFICIARY OF THIS WORK.

MANY HIGH PRIORITY AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES ARE FOUND IN THE FINGER LAKES, SOUTHERN/EASTERN LAKE ONTARIO, AND ST. LAWRENCE SEAWAY AREAS OF NEW YORK'S PART OF THE GREAT LAKES BASIN. NYSDEC REGION 6 INCLUDES EASTERN LAKE ONTARIO AND THE ST. LAWRENCE SEAWAY AS WELL AS INLAND LAKES AND RIVERS IN THE WESTERN ADIRONDACK PARK AND TUG HILL REGION. REGION 8 INCLUDES ERIE CANAL, FINGER LAKES, SOUTHERN LAKE ONTARIO AND ADDITIONAL INLAND LAKES AND RIVERS. NYSDEC INTENDS TO USE FUNDS FOR PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION/RAPID RESPONSE, CONTROL/MANAGEMENT, AND RESEARCH TO FURTHER THE OBJECTIVES OF THE NYS AIS MANAGEMENT PLAN. THE PROPOSED ACTIONS WILL PROTECT NATIVE SPECIES AND HABITATS AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.

DETECTION AND CONTROL EFFORTS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) - FOCUS ON ONEIDA NATURAL AREAS THAT WERE CONTROL BURNED IN 2021 AND NATURAL AREAS THAT WILL BE CONTROL BURNED IN 2022. BY TIMING AND COMBINING HERBICIDE APPLICATIONS AND CONTROLLED BURNS, MAXIMIZING THE TECHNIQUES TO CONTROL INVASIVE PLANTS IN SOME OF THE MOST DIFFICULT LANDSCAPES FOUND IN ONEIDA NATURAL AREAS. FOLLOW UP WITH SPOT TREATMENTS POST CONTROLLED BURNS. ANTICIPATING PROCESS WILL SIGNIFICANTLY DECREASE THE AMOUNT OF HERBICIDE USED OVER A TWO- YEAR PERIOD.THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE MONITORING AND CONTROL OF OVER 200 ACRES OF INVASIVE PLANTS IN OVER NATURAL AREAS OVER THE TWO-YEAR PERIOD. CONFIDENT THAT THESE AREAS CAN BE UTILIZED AS PLACES TO PROVIDE OUTREACH TO THE PUBLIC EITHER THROUGH NEWSPAPER ARTICLES, VIDEOS, OR IN-PERSON GROUPS. TRAINING WILL BE PROVIDED TO STAFF RESPONSIBLE FOR MAINTAINING THE MANY TRAILS AND RESOURCES.PRE-BURN ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE SURVEYING THE AREA WHILE MOWING THE FIREBREAKS, SCHEDULING CONTROL TREATMENTS AT LEAST TWO WEEKS BEFORE THE BURN, AND RE-VISITING THE SITE POST-BURN TO SPOT TREAT AREAS. TIMELINES FOR THE CONTROLLED BURNS WILL VARY DUE TO SCHEDULING WITH BURN CREWS (FOX VALLEY TECHNICAL COLLEGE), WEATHER, PERMITS, BURN PLANS, ETC.

RED SWAMP CRAYFISH (PROCAMBARUS CLARKII) ARE A WORLDWIDE INVADER THAT HAVE THE POTENTIAL TONEGATIVELY IMPACT NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS BY COMPETING WITH NATIVE CRAYFISH SPECIES, ERODINGSHORELINES DUE TO BURROWING BEHAVIOR AND ALTERING WATER QUALITY. THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OFNATURAL RESOURCES (MDNR) WAS NOTIFIED ON JULY 13, 2017 OF THE FIRST INFESTATION OF INVASIVE REDSWAMP CRAYFISH IN MICHIGAN. THE MDNR FISHERIES DIVISION RESPONDED TO THIS INITIAL REPORT ATSUNSET LAKE IN VICKSBURG AND VERIFIED THE PUBLIC REPORT. A SEPARATE CREDIBLE REPORT OF A REDSWAMP CRAYFISH INFESTATION IN A RETENTION POND IN NOVI WAS REPORTED TO THE MDNR ON JULY 17,2017. THESE REPORTS WERE THE FIRST KNOWN ESTABLISHMENTS IN MICHIGAN AND POSE THREATS TOMICHIGAN'S AQUATIC SYSTEMS. IN RESPONSE, THE MDNR-FISHERIES DIVISION PARTNERED WITH MICHIGANSTATE UNIVERSITY TO DEVELOP A RED SWAMP CRAYFISH RESPONSE PLAN. THIS PROJECT WILL EMPHASIZE GOAL FIVE OF THE RESPONSE PLAN, FOCUSING ON IMPLEMENTING AND EVALUATING CONTROL MEASURES TO INCREASE EFFECTIVENESS OF RESPONSE EFFORTS, WITH THE GOAL OF ERADICATING RED SWAMP CRAYFISH. ADDITIONALLY, CONTINUING TO CONDUCT SURVEILLANCE USING THE EARLY DETECTION STRATEGIES DEVELOPED IN PREVIOUS WORK TO IDENTIFY NEWINFESTATIONS (RESPONSE GOALS 1 AND 2) AS WELL AS COLLECT BASELINE BIOLOGICAL AND PHYSICAL DATA THATWILL HELP BETTER UNDERSTAND CRAYFISH POPULATIONS AND THEIR EFFECTS ON NATIVE SYSTEMS (RESPONSEGOAL 4). THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE AS FOLLOWS:IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE CHEMICAL TREATMENTS (E.G., PYRETHRIN AND CO2) AT INFESTEDLOCATIONS IN MICHIGAN, PENDING PERMIT APPROVAL AND THE RESULTS OF ONGOING FIELD AND LABTRIALS- USE INTENSIVE TRAPPING TO CONDUCT CONTROL EFFORTS AND COLLECT INFORMATION TO ADDRESSCRITICAL UNCERTAINTIES- CONDUCT EARLY DETECTION MONITORING USING BAITED TRAPPING TO EVALUATE SPREAD ANDDOCUMENT NEW INFESTATIONS.- IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE BIOCONTROLS THROUGH PREDATORY FISH STOCKING AT INFESTED LOCATIONSTO REDUCE RED SWAMP CRAYFISH POPULATIONS, PENDING THE RESULTS OF ONGOING LABORATORY ANDFIELD TRIALS- ADDRESS MAJOR LIFE HISTORY KNOWLEDGE GAPS (E.G., MOVEMENT AND REPRODUCTION) FOR REDSWAMP CRAYFISH TO HELP DETERMINE VULNERABILITIES THAT CAN BE EXPLOITED AS PART OF ANINTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT STRATEGY (IPM).- COLLECT AND EVALUATE BASELINE BIOLOGICAL AND PHYSICAL INFORMATION THAT WILL INFORM AFUTURE ASSESSMENT OF IMPACTS- USE AVAILABLE INFORMATION AND ANALYSES FROM PAST RESPONSE EFFORTS TO REFINE METHODS IN ANADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK

THE WISCOY CREEK-GREY CABIN TROUT HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND FISH HEALTH IN THE WISCOY CREEK WATERSHED. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE THE STABILIZATION OF 480 FEET OF ERODED STREAMBANK USING RIP RAP AND THE INSTALLATION OF 17 TROUT HABITAT LUNKERS. ALL WORK WILL BE CARRIED OUT BY A SUBCONTRACTOR SELECTED THROUGH A BIDDING PROCESS. THIS WILL PROVIDE 136 FEET OFADDITIONAL HABITAT IN A STRETCH OF THE STREAM THAT LACKS TREE COVER. THE RESTORATION THAT WILL BECOMPLETED ON A SECTION OF THE WISCOY CREEK THAT HAS A PERMANENT PUBLIC FISHING RIGHTS EASEMENTTHROUGH THE NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION (NYS DEC). THE PROJECT WILL ALSO ASSIST NYS DEC FISHERIES TO CONDUCT TROUT POPULATION SURVEYS ALONG THE WISCOY CREEK THAT WILL ASSIST IN FUTURE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS REGARDING THE LOCAL TROUT POPULATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GENETICALLY DETERMINE THE SEX OF INDIVIDUAL LAKE STURGEON TO ANALYZE SEX RATIOS AT LAKE STURGEON ON SPAWNING GROUNDS, NON-SPAWNING AGGREGATES, AND REINTRODUCED POPULATIONS. IN THE LABORATORY, SEX OF EACH INDIVIUDAL FISH WILL BE DETERMINED BY ANALYZING A SMALL TISSUE SAMPLE USING A RECENTLY DEVELOPED GENETIC THAT FACILITATES ACCURATE SEX IDENTIFICATION. THE DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE AN INDIVIDUAL SEX DETERMINATION FOR EACH FISH THAT CONTRIBUTES TO VARIOUS POPULATIONS OF LAKE STRUGEON BEING MANAGED ACROSS THE LAKE SUPERIOR BASIN. THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION NEEDED TO BETTER ASSESS THE OUTCOMES OF LAKE STURGEON MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS IN LAKE SUPERIOR. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS INFORMAITON ARE THE VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE, AND TRIBAL NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES ACROSS THE LAKE SUPERIOR BASIN.

POLLINATORS PROVIDE CRITICAL SERVICES IN NATURAL AND AGRICULTURAL ECOSYSTEMS, BUT UNFORTUNATELY, A NUMBER OF KEY POLLINATOR GROUPS ARE IN DECLINE. A GROWING CONCERN FOR POLLINATOR CONSERVATION IS THE LOSS OF HIGH-QUALITY NATURAL AREAS, SUCH AS PRAIRIE FEN, WET PRAIRIE, SOUTHERN WET MEADOW, AND OTHER SIMILAR WETLAND HABITATS, WHICH ARE NOT ONLY IMPORTANT FOR POLLINATORS BUT ALSO FOR SUPPORTING BIODIVERSITY AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONING. THIS PROPOSED RESEARCH PROJECT WILL BE CONDUCTED IN SOUTHEAST MICHIGAN IN AN INTERFACE BETWEEN URBAN AND WILDLAND HABITATS WITH SURROUNDING AGROECOSYSTEMS. THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INFORM POLLINATOR CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN THE REGION BY INVESTIGATING THE INFLUENCE OF HABITAT MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ON BEES AND BUTTERFLIES AS WELL AS THE PLANT COMMUNITIES THAT SUPPORT THESE POLLINATORS. WE WILL WORK WITH LOCAL-LAND MANAGERS TO PRIORITIZE HABITATS FOR MONITORING TO HELP ASSESS THE ECOLOGICAL IMPACTS OF RECENT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. OUR PROPOSED RESEARCH AIMS TO CONTRIBUTE TO DEVELOPING A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE INFLUENCE OF THESE HABITAT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS ON POLLINATOR ABUNDANCE, DIVERSITY, AND SPECIES INTERACTIONS SO THAT LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES CAN MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS TO IMPROVE HABITAT QUALITY AND CONSERVATION FOR POLLINATORS. THIS PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE HOW PRESCRIBED BURNS AND INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL INFLUENCE PLANT AND POLLINATOR COMMUNITIES ACROSS OPEN GRASSLAND HABITATS THAT SPAN ENVIRONMENTAL GRADIENTS.

SPAWNING HABITAT IN THE EASTERN BASIN OF LAKE ONTARIO IS A LIMITING RESOURCE FOR NUMEROUS NATIVE FISH SPECIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, LAKE STURGEON (ACIPENSER FULVESCENS), WALLEYE (SANDER VITREUS), LAKE TROUT (SALVELINUS NAMAYCUSH) AND CISCOS (COREGONUS SPP.). IMPLEMENTING THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE SPAWNING HABITAT IN THE EASTERN BASIN OF LAKE ONTARIO. FINGER LAKES LAKE ONTARIO WATERSHED PROTECTIONS ALLIANCE, WORKING WITH NUMEROUS PARTNERS INCLUDING THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND THE NY DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION PLANS TO ACCOMPLISH THE RESTORATION OBJECTIVES BY PLACING APPROPRIATELY SIZED SPAWNING BED MATERIAL IN LOCATIONS DETERMINED BY THE PROJECT PARTNERS. THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE APPROXIMATELY 2 ACRES OF SPAWNING HABITAT IN THE EASTERN BASIN OF LAKE ONTARIO, ABOUT ONE ACRE IN THE BLACK RIVER MOUTH AND ONE ACRE IN CHAUMONT BAY. PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION WILL BEGIN IN SUMMER OF 2022 AND CONTINUE UNTIL THE SPAWNING BEDS ARE CONSTRUCTED (APPROXIMATELY 2 MONTHS).

INVASIVE SILVER AND BIGHEAD CARPS (HEREAFTER "BIGHEADED CARPS'') WERE INTRODUCED TO THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER FOLLOWING THEIR ESCAPE FROM AN AQUACULTURE FACILITY IN ARKANSAS IN 1970 AND SUBSEQUENTLY SPREAD THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN INCLUDING THE ILLINOIS RIVER. INVASIVE BIGHEADED CARP HAVE ADVERSE EFFECTS IN RIVERS BY OUTCOMPETING NATIVE SPECIES, ALTERING HABITATS, AND DECREASING WATER QUALITY, LEADING TO DECREASED FISHERIES TARGETING NATIVE SPECIES AND REDUCTION OF WATERFOWL PRODUCTION. IN ADDITION, THEY CAN BE SAFETY HAZARD TO BOATERS BY JUMPING OUT OF THE WATER WHEN STARTLED. A MAJOR CONCERN IS THAT IF THE BIGHEADED CARPS ENTER THE NORTH AMERICAN GREAT LAKES, THEY WILL CAUSE SIMILAR LARGE EFFECTS THERE. AGE-STRUCTURED STOCK ASSESSMENT MODELING IS AN APPROACH THAT CAN BE USED TO ESTIMATE FISH ABUNDANCE AND MORTALITY RATES. THESE MODELS REQUIRE DATA EACH YEAR FOR MANY YEARS OF TOTAL HARVEST AND THE AGE OR SIZE COMPOSITION OF THE HARVEST. IN THE ILLINOIS RIVER, WHICH CONNECTS THE GREAT LAKES TO THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER VIA THE ILLINOIS WATERWAY, THERE IS A PRESSING NEED TO ESTIMATE POPULATION ABUNDANCE AND FISHING MORTALITY RATES OF BIGHEADED CARPS TO DETERMINE WHETHER CURRENT CONTROL MEASURES ARE EFFECTIVE IN LIMITING POPULATION EXPANSION IN THE RIVER. THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A WHITE PAPER THAT ADDRESSES THE FEASIBILITY OF CONSTRUCTING AGE-STRUCTURED STOCK ASSESSMENT MODELS FOR BIGHEAD AND SILVER CARP IN THE ILLINOIS RIVER. THE WHITE PAPER WILL (A) REVIEW EXISTING LITERATURE RELEVANT TO THE BASIC REQUIREMENTS OF AGE-STRUCTURED STOCK ASSESSMENT MODELS AND CHARACTERISTICS OF BIGHEAD AND SILVER CARPS RELEVANT TO SUCH MODELING, (B) SUMMARIZE THE AVAILABLE DATA RELEVANT TO SUCH MODELING (I.E., TYPES AND AMOUNTS OF DATA BY YEAR AND LOCATION), (C) INTERPRET THE DATA AVAILABILITY IN LIGHT OF GENERAL REQUIREMENTS OF AGE-STRUCTURED ASSESSMENT MODELS, (D) MAKES RECOMMENDATIONS ON NEXT STEPS THAT COULD BE UNDERTAKEN USING EXISTING DATA IN STOCK ASSESSMENT MODELING, AND (E) MAKES RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING FUTURE DATA COLLECTION THAT WOULD BETTER SUPPORT STOCK ASSESSMENT MODELING. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE CONTROL PROGRAM FOR BIGHEADED CARP ON THE ILLINOIS RIVER AND HENCE WILL BENEFIT THOSE WHO MAKE USE OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES OF THE RIVER AND THE GREAT LAKES THE RIVER IS CONNECTED TO.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE BY THE DIVISION OF NATURAL AREAS AND PRESERVES (DNAP) PERSONNEL TO CONDUCT THE FOLLOWING ACTIONS TO CENSUS OHIO LAKESIDE DAISY POPULATIONS:
1.	ESTABLISH A SCHEDULE FOR FIELD WORK (MAY-AUGUST)
2.	TRAIN STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS TO IDENTIFY LAKESIDE DAISY AND THE DIFFERENT LIFE STAGES: ADULT, JUVENILE, AND SEEDLING; AS WELL AS THE DENSITY OF PATCHES (CENSUS INFORMATION WILL BE RECORDED ONLY FOR ADULT AND JUVENILE PLANTS)
3.	TRAIN STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS ON METHODS TO COLLECT AND STORE THE DATA THROUGH THE USE OF GPS DEVICES
4.	COLLECT DATA ON THE VARIOUS DENSITY LEVELS OF PLANTS
5.	PREPARE NEEDED PERMITS AND GET LANDOWNER PERMISSION TO ACCESS SITES
6.	COMMUNICATE CLOSELY WITH LANDOWNERS AND VARIOUS AGENCY PERSONNEL (USFWS, ODNR DNAP, ONAPA, LAFARGE, ERIE METROPARKS,) TO DOCUMENT THE STATUS OF FIELD WORK
7.	COMPILE DATA, INCLUDING MAPS OF AREAS WHERE DAISIES EXIST AND AREAS WHERE DAISIES HAVE BEEN EXTIRPATED
8.	AT THE CONCLUSION OF THE PROJECT RECORD ALL PERTINENT DATA IN THE HERITAGE DATABASE AND SUMMARIZE CENSUS ACTIVITIES IN A STAND-ALONE FINAL REPORT INCLUDING MAPS OF SUITABLE AND OCCUPIED HABITAT.
9.	
FUNDS WILL ALSO BE USED TO CONDUCT MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AT NEW AND INTRODUCED OHIO POPULATIONS, SUCH AS:
1.	ENHANCEMENT OF LAKESIDE DAISY HABITAT THROUGH REMOVAL OF CEDAR TREES WHICH CREATE SHADE AND DEGRADE HABITAT
2.	CUT AND STUMP TREAT OTHER WOODY INVASIVES SUCH AS COLUMNAR BUCKTHORN (RHAMNUS FRAGULA `COLUMNARIS'), AUTUMN OLIVE (ELAEAGNUS UMBELLATA), PRIVET (LIGUSTRUM VULGARE), ASIAN BUSH HONEYSUCKLE (LONICERA SP.), CALLERY PEAR (PYRUS CALLERYANA), COTONEASTER (COTONEASTER SP.), ETC.
3.	CUT AND TREATMENT HERBACEOUS INVASIVES SUCH AS PHRAGMITES, MISCANTHUS, PURPLE LOOSESTRIFE (LYTHRUM SALICARIA), SWEET-CLOVER (MELILOTUS OFFICINALIS), ETC.
4.	ESTABLISH A SCHEDULE FOR SEED COLLECTION, TRANSPLANTING, AND SEED DISPERSAL DURING THE FIELD SEASON (MAY-NOVEMBER)
5.	PREPARE NEEDED PERMITS TO COLLECT SEED AND TRANSPLANT PLANTS.
6.	ENSURE THAT APPROPRIATE AMOUNTS OF SEED AND PLANTS ARE COLLECTED EACH YEAR.
7.	SEED SITES WITH LAKESIDE DAISY SEED COLLECTED FROM UNPROTECTED POPULATIONS
8.	TRANSPLANT LAKESIDE INDIVIDUALS FROM UNPROTECTED SITES TO PROTECTED SITES
